articles.headline: ‘Moscow Mitch’ Tag Enrages McConnell and Squeezes G.O.P. on Election Security
articles.snippet: Mr. McConnell, the Senate leader, has typically embraced nasty nicknames by critics. But criticism of his role in blocking election measures has taken hold in an unusual way.
articles.abstract: Mr. McConnell, the Senate leader, has typically embraced nasty nicknames by critics. But criticism of his role in blocking election measures has taken hold in an unusual way.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell is usually impervious to criticism, even celebrating the nasty nicknames critics bestow on him. But Mr. McConnell, the Senate majority leader, is incensed by the name “Moscow Mitch,” and even more miffed that he has been called a “Russian asset” by critics who accuse him of single-handedly blocking stronger election security measures after Russia’s interference in 2016.

articles.headline: Need Extra Time on Tests? It Helps to Have Cash
articles.snippet: Demand for disability accommodations for schoolwork and testing has swelled. But access to them is unequal and the process is vulnerable to abuse.
articles.abstract: Demand for disability accommodations for schoolwork and testing has swelled. But access to them is unequal and the process is vulnerable to abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: The boom began about five years ago, said Kathy Pelzer, a longtime high school counselor in an affluent part of Southern California. More students than ever were securing disability diagnoses, many seeking additional time on class work and tests.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein and Jugal K. Patel

articles.headline: Where Floods of ‘Biblical Proportion’ Drowned Towns and Farms
articles.snippet: Floodwaters swamped more than half a million acres of forest and farmland in the lower Mississippi Delta more than six months ago, gulping up highways and homes, livestock and tractors.
articles.abstract: Floodwaters swamped more than half a million acres of forest and farmland in the lower Mississippi Delta more than six months ago, gulping up highways and homes, livestock and tractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Floodwaters swamped more than half a million acres of forest and farmland in the lower Mississippi Delta more than six months ago, gulping up highways and homes, livestock and tractors. This week, for the first time since, the river gauge at Vicksburg on the western border fell below flood stage.
articles.byline: By Rory Doyle and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: No More Family Separations, Except These 900
articles.snippet: Separations of migrant families are continuing in substantial numbers, often for reasons as simple as a parent with a traffic ticket, the American Civil Liberties Union reported.
articles.abstract: Separations of migrant families are continuing in substantial numbers, often for reasons as simple as a parent with a traffic ticket, the American Civil Liberties Union reported.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the year since President Trump officially ended family separations at the southern border, immigration authorities have removed more than 900 migrant children from their families, sometimes for reasons as minor as a parent not changing a baby’s diaper or having a traffic citation for driving without a license, according to new documents filed Tuesday in federal court.

articles.headline: Capital One Breach Shows a Bank Hacker Needs Just One Gap to Wreak Havoc
articles.snippet: An engineer in Seattle was charged with stealing the information of millions of customers from Capital One. The incident was surprisingly common.
articles.abstract: An engineer in Seattle was charged with stealing the information of millions of customers from Capital One. The incident was surprisingly common.
articles.lead_paragraph: Large financial companies have to thwart hundreds of thousands of cyberattacks every single day. Data thieves have to get lucky only once.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Edelman, Public Relations Giant, Drops Client Over Border Detention Centers
articles.snippet: Fearing its own public relations crisis after an outcry from employees, the company stepped away from the GEO Group, which runs immigration facilities.
articles.abstract: Fearing its own public relations crisis after an outcry from employees, the company stepped away from the GEO Group, which runs immigration facilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May, executives from the giant public relations firm Edelman went to Florida to pitch a potential client: a private prisons company with contracts from the Trump administration to run immigrant detention centers.

articles.headline: Sanders and Warren Battle Accusations of ‘Fairy Tale’ Promises as Intraparty Rift Flares
articles.snippet: Moderate underdogs kicked off the Detroit debates by targeting the top candidates with charges of “wish-list economics” and “impossible promises” on health care.
articles.abstract: Moderate underdogs kicked off the Detroit debates by targeting the top candidates with charges of “wish-list economics” and “impossible promises” on health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The leading liberals in the Democratic presidential primary, Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, strenuously fought back on Tuesday against accusations of making fanciful promises and imperiling the party’s prospects against President Trump, as a group of moderate underdogs sought to slow their momentum in the second round of debates.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Brexit and Boris Johnson Send the British Pound on a Slide
articles.snippet: As investors take stock of the new prime minister and gauge whether Britain will crash out of the European Union, they are selling the currency.
articles.abstract: As investors take stock of the new prime minister and gauge whether Britain will crash out of the European Union, they are selling the currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British pound has long possessed a mystique that transcends its marginal role in the global economy, conjuring memories of its dominance in the imperial age. But lately the currency has devolved into a sign of Britain’s diminishing fortunes in a present dominated by Brexit.

articles.headline: Why the Federal Reserve Cut Interest Rates
articles.snippet: The move is what’s called an “insurance cut” — one that central bankers are making to keep growth chugging along.
articles.abstract: The move is what’s called an “insurance cut” — one that central bankers are making to keep growth chugging along.
articles.lead_paragraph: The move is what’s called an “insurance cut” — one that central bankers are making to keep growth chugging along.
articles.byline: By Karl Russell and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: U.S.-China Trade Talks End With No Deal in Sight
articles.snippet: Negotiators left Shanghai on Wednesday with little immediate sign of progress as both sides appear to be settling in for a long economic clash.
articles.abstract: Negotiators left Shanghai on Wednesday with little immediate sign of progress as both sides appear to be settling in for a long economic clash.
articles.lead_paragraph: American and Chinese negotiators finished talks on Wednesday with little progress toward ending a trade war that has shaken the world’s economic confidence and rattled markets.
